case_name: Writ Petitions Nos. 112, 391-394 of 1971 and 330-31 382-387 of 1974

facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 112, 391-394 of 1971 and 330-31 382-387 of 1974 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 112, 391-394 of 1971 and 330-31 382-387 of 1974. Petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Petitioners are carrying on business in the Union Territories of Goa, Daman and Diu.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are carrying on business in the Union Territories of Goa, Daman and Diu. Respondents 1 and 2 are the Union of India and the Income-tax Officer, respectively.

facts.text: Goa, Daman and Diu became a part of the Union of India on and from December 19, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Goa, Daman and Diu are erstwhile Portuguese territories which became a part of the Union of India on and from December 19, 1961.

facts.text: President promulgated Taxation Laws Extension to Union Territories Regulation III of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the President of India in exercise of powers under Article 240 of the Constitution promulgated the Taxation Laws Extension to Union Territories Regulation III of 1963 for short, the Regulation .

facts.text: Indian Income-tax Act, 1961 extended to Goa, Daman and Diu with effect from April 1, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: By Clause 3 of this Regulation, amongst other laws, the Indian Income-tax Act, 1961 for short, the Act was extended to the Union Territory of Goa, Daman and Diu with effect from April 1, 1963

facts.text: Clause 4 of the Regulation repealed laws in force in the Union Territory corresponding to the Acts specified in the Schedule from April 1, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: By Clause 4 of the Regulation, te laws in force in the Union Territory companyresponding to the Acts specified in the Schedule, stand repealed from April 1, 1963.

facts.text: Central Government promulgated Taxation Laws Extension to Union Territories Removal of Difficulties Order No. 2 of 1970 on November 8, 1970 under Clause 7 of the Regulation.

anchor.surface_text: On November 8, 1970, the Central Government in purported exercise of its powers under Clause 7 of the Regulation promulgated the Taxation Laws Extension to Union Territories Removal of Difficulties Order No. 2 of 1970

facts.text: The 1970 Order deemed to have come into force on April 1, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: 1 It shall be deemed to have companye into force on the 1st day of April 1963.

facts.text: Under Portuguese law in Goa, Daman and Diu, tax was levied on gross income or turnover without provision for depreciation allowance.

anchor.surface_text: In these territories, there was in force a Portuguese law relating to levy of tax, the scheme of which was entirely different from that of the Indian Income-tax Act. Under that law there was numberprovision for granting depreciation allowance

facts.text: Petitioners assessed under Indian Income-tax Act for assessment years from 1964-65 onwards with depreciation allowed on actual cost initially.

anchor.surface_text: After the extension of the Act to Goa, Daman and Diu, the petitioners were assessed under the Act for several assessment years from 1964-65 onwards.

facts.text: Past completed assessments of petitioners being revised in light of 2nd Proviso to Clause 3 of 1970 Order.

anchor.surface_text: In the light of the 2nd Proviso to Clause 3 of the 1970 Order, the past companypleted assessments in the case of these petitioners are being revised.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer revised assessment for 1965-66 of petitioners in Writ Petitions 330-331 of 1971 and raised higher demand kept in abeyance.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of petitioners in Writ Petitions 330-331- of 1971, the Respondent Income-tax Officer has already revised the assessment for the year 1965-66, and reduced the depreciation allowed in view of the 1970 Order

facts.text: 2nd Proviso to Clause 3 of 1970 Order provides for calculating depreciation where none was allowed under local law at rates under Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Provided further that where in respect of any period numberdepreciation was actually allowed under the local law or the depreciation actually allowed cannot be ascertained, depre- ciation in respect of that period shall be calculated at the rate for the time being in force under the Income-tax Act, 1961

facts.text: Judgment delivered by R. S. Sarkaria J., with dissenting opinion by A. Alagiriswami J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by R. S. Sarkaria, A. Alagiriswami, J. gave a dissenting Opinion.

facts.text: Petitions argued by K. Sen in W.P. No. 112/71 and N. A. Palkhiwala in others.

anchor.surface_text: K. Sen In W.P. No. 112/71 , N. A. Palkhiwala In W.P. 330331 and 382-387/74 , S. P. Mehta, P. C. Bhartari, J. B. Dadachanji, G. C. Mathur, Arati Mehta and Ravinder Narain, for the petitioners.

facts.text: Respondents represented by S. Nariman, Additional Solicitor General, P. P. Rao and P. Nayar.

anchor.surface_text: S. Nariman, Additional Solicitor General, P. P. Rao and P. Nayar, for the respondents.

facts.text: Court holds 2nd Proviso to Clause 3 of 1970 Order ultra vires Clause 7 of Regulation III of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons, we allow these petitions and declare that the 2nd Proviso to Clause 3 of the Taxation Laws Extension to Union Territories Removal of Difficulties Order 2 of 1970, is ultra vires the Central Government

facts.text: No difficulty arose in applying Income-tax Act to assessees in Goa, Daman and Diu as objective fact.

anchor.surface_text: The Court held that after the promulgation of the 1949 Order numberdifficulty survived or arose in giving effect to the provisions of s.10 of the 1922 Act.

facts.text: Between December 19, 1961 and April 1, 1963, no income-tax law in force in Goa, Daman and Diu.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, during the interregnum between December 19, 1661 and April 1, 1963, there .was in force numberlaw authorising the, levy of income-tax in these Territories.

facts.text: Alagiriswami J. dissents and upholds validity of the 1970 Order.

anchor.surface_text: I would, therefore, dismiss these writ petitions.

facts.text: Petitioners claim no difficulty established for invoking Clause 7 power.

anchor.surface_text: Relying on the ratio of this Courts decision in Straw Products Ltd v. Income-tax Officer, Bhopal 1 , learned Counsel for the petitioners have pressed these points into argument The arising of a difficulty

facts.text: Respondents claim difficulties arose in allowing depreciation to assessees in Union Territories.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Nariman, learned Additional Solicitor-General, submits, in reply, that difficulties had arisen in the application of the provisions of the Act in the matter of allowing depreciation to assessees in these Union Territories.

facts.text: Assessees in merged states like Bhopal had tax exemption leading to no actual depreciation allowed.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee therein was a Company formed in 1937 in Bhopal State and was exempted by the Ruler of that State from payment of all taxes for a period of ten years expiring on October 31, 1948.

facts.text: State of Bhopal merged with India on August 1, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bhopal merged with India on August 1, 1949.

facts.text: In Straw Products case, 1962 Amendment Order struck down by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Both these companytentions were accepted by the Court and, as a result, the aforesaid sub-clause b of the Explanation was struck down.

issues.text: Whether the 2nd Proviso to Clause 3 of the Taxation Laws Extension to Union Territories Removal of Difficulties Order 2 of 1970 is valid?

anchor.surface_text: These writ petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution raise a question with regard to the validity of the 2nd Proviso to Clause  3  of the Taxation Laws  Extension to Union Territories   Removal of Difficulties  Order 2 of 1970. The first five petitions of 1971 were urged earlier by Shri Ashok Sen and the rest have been argued

issues.text: Whether the arising of a difficulty in giving effect to the Indian Income-tax Act is a condition precedent to the invocation of the power under Clause 7 of the Regulation, and whether such difficulty was established as an objective fact?

anchor.surface_text: The arising of a difficulty in giving effect to the Indian Income-tax Act or rules etc., made thereunder is a condition precedent to the invocation of the power under Clause  7  of the Regulation, and since the existence of that condition had not been established as an objective fact, the Central Government had no power to promulgate the impugned Proviso.

issues.text: Whether the power under Clause 7 of the Regulation can be exercised in a manner consistent with the scheme and essential provisions of the Act, or can it provide for determining written-down value on notional depreciation inconsistent with ss. 32 and 43(6)?

anchor.surface_text: The power under Clause  7  of the Regulation can be exercised only in a manner consistent with the scheme and essential provisions of the Act. The impugned proviso seeks to amend and change the scheme and basic provisions of the Act inasmuch as it provides, inconsistently with ss.43 6  and 32 of the Act,

issues.text: Whether the impugned proviso is workable?

anchor.surface_text: In any case, it would be impossible to work the impugned Proviso.

issues.text: Is this a difficulty within the contemplation of Clause 7 of the Regulation?

anchor.surface_text: This raises two questions  1  Is this a difficulty within the contemplation of Clause  7  of the Regulation ?

issues.text: Is the Central Government in the exercise of its power under Clause 7 competent to supply a deficiency or omission of this nature?

anchor.surface_text: Is the Central Government in the exercise of its power under that Clause competent to supply a deficiency or omission of this nature ?

issues.text: Whether the order given retrospective effect is valid?

anchor.surface_text: the further contention raised that the order is given retrospective effect and that is not valid.

holdings.text: The 2nd Proviso to Clause 3 of the Taxation Laws Extension to Union Territories Removal of Difficulties Order 2 of 1970 is ultra vires the Central Government when exercising powers under Clause 7 of Regulation III of 1963

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons, we allow these petitions and declare that the 2nd Proviso to Clause  3  of the Taxation Laws  Extension to Union Territories   Removal of Difficulties  Order 2 of 1970, is ultra vires the Central Government

holdings.reasoning_summary: No objective difficulty established as condition precedent; proviso alters scheme of ss.32, 43(6) by deeming fictional depreciation; unworkable due to interregnum lacking machinery for pre-1963 assessments

holdings.text: Arising of difficulty under Clause 7 is condition precedent that must exist as objective fact, not subjective satisfaction

anchor.surface_text: Exercise of the power to make provisions or to issue directions as may appear necessary to the Central Government is conditioned by the existence of a difficulty arising in giving effect to the provisions of any Act, rule or order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Straw Products; past assessments from 1964-65 applied Act without issue using actual cost as WDV since no prior depreciation

holdings.text: No difficulty arose in giving effect to Income-tax Act provisions in Goa, Daman, Diu as demonstrated by completed assessments

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the contention that but for the impugned Proviso, the provisions of s. 32 and s. 43  6   b  of the 1961 Act on its extension to Goa, Daman and Diu

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessments computed WDV as actual cost less nil depreciation under cl.(b) s.43(6); no need for proviso

holdings.text: Power under Clause 7 limited to minor peripheral adjustments to make Act workable; cannot change basic scheme or essential provisions like depreciation and WDV

anchor.surface_text: the legislature sometimes thinks it expedient to invest the Executive with a very limited power to make minor adaptations and peripheral adjustments in the statute

holdings.reasoning_summary: Removal clauses like Henry VIII allow smoothing edges but not violence to structure; proviso substitutes fictional for actual depreciation, altering ss.32,43(6)

holdings.text: 2nd Proviso unworkable as no machinery for retrospective pre-1963 assessments during interregnum; prevents carry-forward of unabsorbed depreciation

anchor.surface_text: Be that as it may, the last contention... the impugned Proviso is not workable, because, under the Portuguese law there was no tax on income at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Portuguese turnover tax computed no profits/losses; interregnum 1961-63 no income-tax law; impossible to ascertain past losses for s.32(2) carry-forward

holdings.text: "Actually allowed" in s.43(6)(b) means depreciation given effect to and debited in past assessments, not notional or fictional

anchor.surface_text: The definition of actual cost is to be found in s. 43 1 and that of written-down value in s. 43  6 . The later defines it to mean-  a  in the case of assets acquired

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation; antithesis of speculative; where none allowed previously, WDV equals actual cost less nil

holdings.text: Central Government not competent under Clause 7 to supply deficiency by deeming fictional depreciation where none allowed under prior local law

anchor.surface_text: Is the Central Government in the exercise of its power under that Clause competent to supply a deficiency or omission of this nature ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous to struck-down 1962 Order in Straw Products; changes essence of WDV definition

holdings.text: Power under removal clause includes retrospective effect from when difficulty arose, if power validly invoked

anchor.surface_text: the order is given retrospective effect and that is not valid. This contention is best answered... power to remove the difficulty must necessarily include

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inherent in purpose to remove past difficulties; quoting Ramgopal Mills

holdings.text: Impugned 2nd Proviso valid under Clause 7 as it harmonises depreciation scheme and removes disparity

anchor.surface_text: I would, therefore, dismiss these writ petitions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Difficulty exists as cl.(b) s.43(6) inapplicable without repeal by IT Act; fictional depreciation accords with realities and scheme per Ramgopal; workable via accounts

precedents.citation: Badridas Degu v. Commissioner of Income-tax 34 I.T.R. 10 S.C.

anchor.surface_text: see Badridas Degu v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1  and Commissioner of Income-tax v. Plymaun.  2  We have alluded to these general principles for a proper perspective. Dedications by way of depreciation allowance, with which we are directly companyserned, have been specifically recognised and dealt with in ss. 3 2, 34 and 43  6  of the Act. Section 32 adopts two methods in allowing depreciation.

precedents.case_name: Badridas Degu v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: the deduction of a particular item from the incoming of the business, or profession is neither expressly covered by the aforesaid sections, nor prohibited expressly or by necessary implication by those provisions, it can be allowed under S. 28(1) provided on ordinary commercial principles, it is a proper item to be debited against the incoming in ascertaining the profits and gains properly so-called

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Plymaun 46 I.T.R. 649 S.C.

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Plymaun.  2  We have alluded to these general principles for a proper perspective. Dedications by way of depreciation allowance, with which we are directly concerned, have been specifically recognised and dealt with in ss. 32, 34 and 43(6) of the Act. Section 32 adopts two methods in allowing depreciation.

precedents.cited_proposition: the deduction of a particular item from the incoming of the business, or profession is neither expressly covered by the aforesaid sections, nor prohibited expressly or by necessary implication by those provisions, it can be allowed under S. 28(1) provided on ordinary commercial principles, it is a proper item to be debited against the incoming in ascertaining the profits and gains properly so-called

anchor.surface_text: Relying on the ratio of this Courts decision in Straw Products Ltd v. Income-tax Officer, Bhopal 1 , learned Counsel for the petitioners have pressed these points into argument The arising of a difficulty in giving effect to the Indian Income-tax Act or rules etc., made thereunder is a condition precedent to the invocation of the power under Clause  7  of the Regulation,

precedents.case_name: Straw Products Ltd v. Income-tax Officer, Bhopal
precedents.cited_proposition: arising of a difficulty in giving effect to the provisions is a condition precedent which must be established as an objective fact; power under removal of difficulty clause cannot be used to change the scheme and essential provisions of the Act
precedents.cited_holding: the impugned Order which seeks in purported exercise of the power, to remove a difficulty which had not arisen was, therefore, unauthorised

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madhya Pradesh v. Straw Products 1964 2 S.C.R. 881, 887

anchor.surface_text: On this point reliance has been placed on Commissioner of Income-tax, Madhya Pradesh v. Straw Products 1  and Commissioner of Income-tax Hyderabad v. Dewan Bahadur RamGopal Mills Ltd. 2 . Since both sides rely, more or less, on the decision of this Court in Straw Products Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Bhopal  supra  and the other two authorities cited have also been noticed therein,

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madhya Pradesh v. Straw Products
precedents.cited_proposition: the expression actually allowed in the Removal of Difficulties Order 1949, meant allowance actually given effect to, but by virtue of the Explanation added by the 1962 Order, the correct basis for computing the written down value was the one adopted by the Income-tax officer

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax Hyderabad v. Dewan Bahadur RamGopal Mills Ltd. 1961 2 S.C.R. 318, 325

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax Hyderabad v. Dewan Bahadur RamGopal Mills Ltd. 2 . Since both sides rely, more or less, on the decision of this Court in Straw Products Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Bhopal  supra  and the other two authorities cited have also been noticed therein, it will be appropriate to examine the same in detail.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Hyderabad v. Dewan Bahadur RamGopal Mills Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: the Explanation added did not change the basic connotation of depreciation actually allowed, it only clarified it; valid exercise under removal of difficulty power
precedents.cited_holding: upheld the validity of the impugned provision

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad v. Dewan Bahadur Ramgopal Mills Ltd. 1961 2 SCR 318

anchor.surface_text: As was pointed out by this Court in its decisions in The Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad v. Dewan Bahadur Ramgopal Mills Ltd. 1961.  2 SCR 318 and the Straw Products Ltd. v. I.T.O. 1968  2 SCR 1, this is one difficulty to remove which a Difficulties Removal Order would have had to be issued.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad v. Dewan Bahadur Ramgopal Mills Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: difficulty arose because earlier law not repealed by Indian IT Act, requiring removal order

precedents.citation: Straw Products Ltd. v. I.T.O. 1968 2 SCR 1

anchor.surface_text: 2 SCR 318 and the Straw Products Ltd. v. I.T.O. 1968  2 SCR 1, this is one difficulty to remove which a Difficulties Removal Order would have had to be issued. precedents.cited_proposition: difficulty arose because earlier law not repealed by Indian IT Act, requiring removal order

anchor.surface_text: as was pointed out by this Court in Ramgopal Mills case  supra  in the following words The basic and normal scheme of depreciation under the Indian Income-tax Act is that it decreases every year, being a percentage of the written down value which in the first year is the actual cost and in succeeding years actual cost less all depreciation actually allowed under the Income-tax Act or any Act repealed thereby etc.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Hyderabad v. Dewan Bahadur Ramgopal Mills Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: basic and normal scheme of depreciation under the Indian Income-tax Act is that it decreases every year, being a percentage of the written down value

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons, we allow these petitions and declare that the 2nd Proviso to Clause  3  of the Taxation Laws  Extension to Union Territories   Removal of Difficulties  Order 2 of 1970, is ultra vires the Central Government when exercising the powers under Clause  7  ,of Regulation IIII of 1963 and the Revenue authorities are number entitled to levy tax on the basis of the depreciation allowance companyputed in. accordance with the said Proviso in the , Order. The respondents, shall pay, the companyts of the petitioners.

outcome.relief_summary: Writ petitions allowed; 2nd Proviso to Clause 3 of the 1970 Order declared ultra vires Clause 7 of Regulation III of 1963; Revenue authorities not entitled to levy tax based on depreciation computed under the Proviso
directions: Revenue authorities are not entitled to levy tax on the basis of the depreciation allowance computed in accordance with the said Proviso in the Order
